item.title: Monitoring California's Coastal Biodiversity With Citizen Science
item.description: Citizen science can generate biodiversity data at scales intractable for other approaches. We are building the capacity to use citizen science observations to monitor biodiversity on the California coast.

item.title: Planning for the Large-Scale Conservation of Biodiversity Dimensions
item.description: Given monetary constraints, large-scale biodiversity conservation policies need to be selective with respect to the areas and species they prioritize. Macroecological knowledge can help make those challenging decisions.

item.title: Understanding Past Distribution Changes of Species and Communities
item.description: Documenting and understanding how species and ecosystems have responded to environmental changes in the past is critical to improving our ability to predict their likely future responses.

item.title: Improving Predictions of Species' Future Distribution Changes
item.description: A large number of statistical approaches are being developed to forecast the potential future responses of species and communities to environmental change. But how good are those predictions?

item.title: cv
Understanding How Biodiversity is Distributed in Space and Time
item.description: Understanding how and why biodiversity is distributed the way it is across space and time is key to generating reliable predictions of biodiversity in unexplored regions or future time periods.

item.title: Biosketch
item.description: Giovanni Rapacciuolo is a biodiversity data scientist and macroecologist. His work at the macroecology–conservation practice interface takes advantage of emerging approaches for analyzing and visualizing big datasets to improve our predictive understanding of large-scale biodiversity change and support conservation decisions. Giovanni is currently a Research Scientist at the California Academy of Sciences in San Francisco. Find me on Email | Twitter | LinkedIn | GoogleScholar | GitHub | ResearchGate | Publons
